entry.title: Storage Bins Upload in SAP EWM using transaction code /N/SCWM/SBUP
entry.content:
Steps to perform Storage Bin Upload in SAP EWM using transaction code /N/SCWM/SBUP:

Step 1:
Navigate to the "Load Storage Bin" option from the SAP Easy Access screen, or directly enter the transaction code /SCWM/SBUP.

Step 2:
The Load Storage Bin screen will appear. Click on the folder icon to proceed with file selection.

Step 3:
Select the input file in CSV format, which must include the following fields:

  • Warehouse Number
  • Storage Bin
  • Storage Type
    Click on the Upload button to import the data.

Step 4:
If prompted with the "SAP GUI Security" dialog box, check the "Remember My Decision" option and click Allow to proceed.

 

Step 5:
The system will display a preview of the records from the input file.


Click the Create icon. A confirmation message will appear:
"1 storage bin created"

Step 6:
You can verify the created storage bin using transaction codes /n/SCWM/MON (Warehouse Monitor) or /n/SCWM/LS03 (Display Storage Bin).

Conclusion:

This guide outlines the steps to upload storage bins in SAP EWM using transaction code /SCWM/SBUP, allowing for efficient bin creation from a CSV input file.

entry.title: Solution for SAP Error message "Party Entitled to dispose is not allowed in warehouse number"
entry.content:
Party Entitled to Dispose:

  • The Party Entitled to Dispose refers to the organizational unit that owns the stock in SAP EWM.

  • It determines who has the legal right to make decisions about the goods (e.g., transfer, sell).

  • This is critical in third-party logistics or shared warehouse scenarios to segregate stock ownership.

 

PSA (Production Supply Area):

  • A production supply area is a logical area near a production line where materials are supplied for manufacturing.

  • It connects warehouse processes with production orders in SAP EWM and S/4HANA.

  • PSAs ensure the right materials are staged and available at the right location for production.

 

PSA Staging:

  • PSA staging is the process of transferring required components from the warehouse to the production supply area.

  • It is triggered by a production order and can be handled manually or automatically.

  • SAP EWM manages PSA staging through warehouse tasks and delivery-based staging methods.

 

Storage Locations:

  • A storage location in SAP defines a specific physical or logical area within a plant where materials are stored.

  • It helps organize inventory for easier tracking and management.

  • Storage locations are essential for stock segregation, valuation, and inventory management processes.

 

The error message "Party entitled to dispose is not allowed in warehouse number" displays when maintaining the PSA staging.

 

Why it’s required to maintain:

The new entry should be maintained for the production supply area staging cutover activity in production. This is required to ensure the following two:

  1. Determination of the storage bin for staging to the PSA
  2. Determination of the storage bin for the consumption of products from the PSA

 

Solution for the error message:

The following entries need to be maintained in the production system for "Mapping storage locations from the ERP system to EWM".

 

Once the required configuration is created, PSA staging can be maintained as shown in the below screenshot.

entry.title: EWM Queue Error “Field Item: Batch Number is a require field for the action HDR: PDO save Document"
entry.content:
In this blog, queues which are failed due to error message "Field Item: Batch Number is a require field for the action HDR: PDO save Document" will be resolved with step by step approach.

Issue Overview:

An Inbound Delivery is created without a batch number for a material which is maintained as batch-managed in material master.
Upon saving the delivery, its status changes to “B” (Distributed).As a result, an EWM inbound queue error occurs with the message:

“Field Item: Batch Number is a required field for the action HDR: PDO Save Document Header.”

Steps to replicate the Issue:

Step 1:
Check in.material master to confirm that the material is batch-managed.

 

Step2:

The Inbound delivery as displayed in the below screenshot is created without batch

 

Step3:

On Saving the delivery, header status - Dec Whse for the delivery is changed to “B” (Distributed).

 

The EWM Error queue error occurs with the message as “Field Item: Batch Number is a require field for the action HDR: PDO save Document Header”

 

 

Solution to resolve the EWM Queue:

Step1:

To resolve this , intial step is to save the queue with error using the transaction code SMQ2.

 

Step2:

From transaction code SE37, execute FM (Function Module) :  /SPE/DELV_RESET_DIST_STATUS

 

Once executed - this will reset the delivery’s distribution status from "B" (Distributed) to "A" (Relevant).

 

 

 

 

 Step3:

Delivery is now open and can be changes - hence a new batch can be created or assigned for the line items in the inbound delivery.

 

Step4:

Once completed - save S4 inbound delivery to  re-trigger the distribution to EWM, with updated batch information included, to process queues sucessfully.

 

Conclusion:

Provided  solution resolves EWM queue error “Field Item: Batch Number is a required field for the action HDR: PDO Save Document Header” by resetting the distribution status, maintaining batch data, and successfully re-distributing the delivery to EWM.

entry.title: Stock Upload in SAP EWM using the Transaction Code /N/SCWM/ISU
entry.content:
Steps to perform for Stock Upload in SAP EWM using the Transaction Code /N/SCWM/ISU

Step 1:
Navigate to “Stock Data Transfer” in the SAP Easy Access menu or directly enter the transaction code /N/SCWM/ISU.

 

 

Step 2:
The Stock Data Transfer screen will appear.
Enter Warehouse Number, and click on the folder icon to select input file.

 

 

Step 3:
Navigate to the upload file as displayed in the screenshot, and select on the Upload button to upload data.

Prompt with the "SAP GUI Security" dialog box will be displayed, check “Remember My Decision” and click “Allow” .

 

Step 4:
Uploaded data will be displayed in the highlighted section.

Click the Execute button to process the stock upload.

 

Step 5:
A Warehouse Task will be automatically created for the uploaded stock.

 

 

Step 6:
To verify the uploaded material and quantity, go to transaction /N/SCWM/MON (Warehouse Monitor).

 

Step 7:
In the background, movement type 561 is triggered to post the stock into the ERP system.
You can verify this posting in transaction MB51.

 

Conclusion:

Steps to perform Stock Upload in SAP EWM using the Transaction Code /N/SCWM/ISU is provided.

entry.title: SAP EWM Physical Inventory with /SCWM/PI_COUNTLIST
entry.content:
As an SAP EWM consultant, I often come across warehouses that still rely on paper-based inventory counts. Not every site uses RF devices or mobile solutions for physical inventory. For those environments, SAP provides a very handy transaction: /SCWM/PI_COUNTLIST.

In this blog, I’d like to share a quick insight into /SCWM/PI_COUNTLIST tcode. Whether you're printing paper-based count lists or just exploring physical inventory processes, this blog will help you get started.

 

The /SCWM/PI_COUNTLIST transaction takes the items from your physical inventory (PI) documents and formats them in a structured layout that warehouse staff can use to record counted quantities by hand. This is especially helpful in warehouses without RF devices.

As follows once a PI document has been created (/SCWM/PI_CREATE), you can use /SCWM/PI_COUNTLIST by entering PI document number.

Mark the "Storage Bin Empty" checkbox if the storage bin is physically empty, or select "PI Zero Count" if no stock is found for that specific material during the physical count.

Use the "Quantity in AUoM" field to enter the actual counted quantity in the alternative unit of measure as shown in the screenshot above.

Also by selecting the relevant item and clicking the "Display PI Doc Item" button, the system will navigate you directly to the /SCWM/PI_PROCESS screen, where you can view and enter the physical inventory details.

While /SCWM/PI_COUNTLIST is great for many physical inventory scenarios, it's important to understand that this transaction was designed primarily for simple stock structures such as products placed directly in storage bins, or basic cases like a product in a handling unit (HU), with the HU stored in a bin.

However, it does not support complex inventory structures, such as handling unit hierarchies and serial number managed products.

If you're working with any of these scenarios you should use /SCWM/PI_PROCESS or /SCWM/PI_COUNT instead. These transactions provide more flexibility and visibility for complex counting scenarios. (https://me.sap.com/notes/3265297/E)

 

Even in today’s digital warehouses, manual processes still exist and sometimes they’re necessary. /SCWM/PI_COUNTLIST helps bridge the gap between system data and manual operations. It gives warehouse workers a clear, organized way to count stock and ensures that physical inventory processes stay reliable, even without mobile tools.

This was a small but useful function that I believe doesn’t get enough attention. If your site handles manual counting make sure you check out /SCWM/PI_COUNTLIST. It’s simple to use, easy to adjust, and can make physical inventory runs much smoother.

 

Thanks for reading!

Note;

If you performed your physical inventory count using Excel and want to upload the results into the system all at once, you can use the PI_UPLOAD process and for that you can check the following blog post;

https://community.sap.com/t5/supply-chain-management-blog-posts-by-members/ewm-physical-inventory-pi-upload-transaction/ba-p/13430503

 

References

Processing of Physical Inventory Documents | SAP Help Portal

Compare Physical Inventory IM - WM - EWM - SAP Community

About the limitations;

https://me.sap.com/notes/3265297/E

https://me.sap.com/notes/3375080/E

https://me.sap.com/notes/3401785/E

entry.title: Complete your Advanced Shipping & Receiving (ASR) process with a PGI event
entry.content:
A common requirement in TM-EWM projects is the need to update the execution status or report an event on freight orders after the PGI. When configuring the Advanced Shipping & Receiving process, it is possible to specify the event that should be reported after the goods movement in the outbound processes.

This makes it possible to make your process more agile and cohesive, and to provide feedback to your freight order with all the necessary information, aiming to have a single point of reference for the process progress.

For this purpose, SAP provides the TM Save Strategy called PGI_REP_EV shown in the print below, which must be configured in the freight orders relevant to the ASR process:

After the entire process is executed in the ASR, our freight order will have these events, where the next step is the execution of the PGI and then the departure from door, which are executed in the Load or Unload Freight Orders app. Without the above configuration, only during the "departure from door" step is an event reported, which in this case is "Departure From Door".

This way we go to the "Load or unload Freight Orders" App and perform the PGI:

And this way, the "Checkout" event is reported. Additionally, according to the ASR process itself, the "Departure From Door" event is automatically reported. This occurs through the /scmtms/cl_tor_set_dep_wh_door-set_wh_door_departed class/method, which performs a series of additional checks to report this additional event along with the "Checkout" event. This way, we complete the entire process with just the PGI.

Therefore, it will not be necessary to run this departure process on the monitor:

An important point is that it's possible to configure the event that will be reported for this strategy. As mentioned above, the reported event was "Checkout". This event was determined through a process controller parameter linked to the method and the standard strategy. However, the class is prepared to be configured with a custom strategy (ZPGI_REP_E) and a custom parameter (ZEVENT_CODE), so you can determine which event will be reported via configuration:

To do this:

  • Create your own strategy according to the name described in the code and include the same method as the standard strategy
  • Create the parameter also with the custom name described
  • And then assign the event code to the parameter and strategy in this last menu of the process controller configuration:

entry.title: The SAP Extended Warehouse Management FAQ Series: SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud Integration
entry.content:
Many customers running standardized processes for their Finance, Controlling and Order Management processes in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud are searching for options to integrate advanced warehouse management functionalities to cover their logistics process requirements and help them to grow their business.

With SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508 a new scope item enabling integration of SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud with EWM for SAP S/4HANA Private Cloud will be available, to combine standardized cloud ERP processes to be integrated with advanced warehouse management capabilities.

With this blog post are discussing questions and interesting information around the integration of SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud and EWM for SAP S/4HANA Private Cloud.

Which release is required to setup the SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud and EWM for SAP S/4HANA Private Cloud integration?

With SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508 a new scope item will be shipped - SAP EWM for SAP S/4HANA Integration (7L1). This includes the new communication scenario Logistics - S/4HANA Extended Warehouse Management Integration (SAP_COM_0A58) that enables the integration of transactional data to a decentral EWM for SAP S/4HANA Private Cloud or OnPremise.

Minimum required SAP S/4HANA Private Cloud release is 2023, FPS0 if batch master data distribution is not required. Otherwise, SAP S/4HANA Private Cloude release 2023, FPS3, introducing the batch master data distribution via DRF is the required minimum release.

Which functional scope is supported in the integration?

The following processes are supported in the SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud integration to a decentral EWM for SAP S/4HANA Private Cloud:

Process

see also Scope Item

Inbound processing from supplier

2VJ - SAP EWM Integration - Inbound Processing from Supplier

Outbound processing to customer

2VK - SAP EWM Integration - Outbound Processing to Customer

Delivery based production integration: Production supply and goods receipt

2VM - SAP EWM Integration - Delivery-Based Production Integration

Customer returns

2VO - SAP EWM Integration - Customer Returns 

Batch management - Creating batches in: 

•       SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition ERP system

•       SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition EWM system

2VN - SAP EWM Integration - Batch Management

Stock transport orders

2VL - SAP EWM Integration - Stock Transport Orders 

What do I have to know about the technical setup of the integration?

To setup the integration there are cut-over, customizing and integration settings required to establish the integration from SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud to SAP S/4HANA Private Cloud via SAP Cloud Connector and vice versa via WebSocket. Please find detailed information about the integration via official Set-Up Instruction - Setting Up SAP EWM for SAP S/4HANA Integration (7L1).

Which deployment scenarios are supported?

We are supporting the integration of a single SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud tenant (with or without Cloud WM) to a single EWM for SAP S/4HANA Private Cloud instance. Additionally, a further SAP S/4HANA Private Cloud instance can be integration to the same EWM for SAP S/4HANA.

Please note that the SAP S/4HANA Private Cloud instance can only be used as a decentral EWM logistics system as the integration of multiple SAP S/4HANA or SAP ECC systems to EWM on SAP S/4HANA embedded not supported (see also SAP Note 3376453 - SAP S/4HANA 2023 FPS00, FPS01, FPS02 and FPS03: Release information and restrictions for EWM in SAP S/4HANA).

Are there any restriction to be considered implementing this integration to EWM for SAP S/4HANA Private Cloud?

There are functional restrictions for EWM on SAP S/4HANA Private Cloud integrating with SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud to be considered. These can be distinguished by supported processes and integration capabilities managed via Control Parameters for ERP Version Control.

Please find a list of most important processes and functions not supported in the integration in the table below:

Process/Functions

Details

Handling Unit Management in EWM in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition

Handling Units can only be managed within SAP EWM. They are not integrated into SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud Edition. Handling Units created in EWM for SAP S/4HANA Private Cloud are not transferred to deliveries in the SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud Edition.

Serial Numbers on warehouse level

SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition offers Serial Numbers on the document level (A), the warehouse level (B) and the stock level (C). SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition only offers Serial Numbers on the (A) document and (C) stock levels.​ Serial Number on document and stock level supported for integration scenario only.

Transport Integration – Shipment (LE-TRA) – Transportation Unit

Integration of Transportation Units via SHPMNT05-Idoc to LE-TRA component (Shipments) is not supported in SAP S/4HANA Private Cloud integration.

Integration with SAP Transportation Management (TM)

The integration with Transportation Management (e.g. Via Transportation Units or Advanced Shipping and Receiving) is not supported.

Find a complete list of restrictions and learn more about the new integration between SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud and EWM for SAP S/4HANA Private Cloud via SAP Note 3629180 - Supported Processes for EWM Integration with SAP_COM_0A58 - SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508 and Higher.

Learn more about this integration via SAP Help - SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508 - Feature Scope Description.

entry.title: How to handle Stock Specific UOM at Product level
entry.content:
Business Problem: Customer has different product in the warehouse in which some products should be updated in Alternative UoM(AUoM)  and some products should be updated in Base Unit of measure BUoM during stock placement against IBD or receiving against Manufacturing Order( Production Or Process Order).

Strictly for some products, customer requirement is to prevent AUoM data being transferred into the stock attributes( Highlighted in Yellow), however for some it should have mix in the same Storage Type( Product ending with 568)

Stock Specific UOM at UOM/Whse Level.

  • The SUoM relevance is maintained on UoM level in SPRO. The product does not have any influence in the customizing activity. Nevertheless, there might be products that share the same alternative UoM (e.g. CAR for carton). But, some of them should follow SUoM processes and others not.

Solution:  To handle these kinds of Mix stock scenario in same storage type level, SAP has given 2 solution based on Business needs and complexity

  • Usage of Product Putaway Profile- Customizing entry
  • Badi /SCWM/EX_MD_FLG_SUOM_DET

The blog will discuss how to handle Product Specific SUoM for the same storage type using product Putaway Profile.

Take a product having BUoM  to AUoM conversion.

 CV and PAL both are activated as SUoM at whse level.

Activate the required storage type config to store stock based on product Putaway Profile( Either BUoM or AUoM).

The first product in the above example needs to be stored in BUoM only and hence below setting is activated at product putaway profile level to store stock at BUoM only and prevent AUoM data being transferred into the stock attributes( in Whse Monitor)

Assign the PTWY control indicator which controls Product Putaway profile config as well in MAT1

Performing the receiving activity( REHU MO)

After during Warehouse Task confirmation, TASK was created in PAL( AUoM) as explained in NOTE 2745415 - AUoM during Warehouse Task creation.

However, after task confirmation, Both QTY is BUoM only

Actual Stock situation before and after activation of Product Pty Profile

Customer can implement /SCWM/EX_MD_FLG_SUOM_DET BAdI to define at the product level, whether or not particular UoMs are stock-specific for particular products.

Please implement all the notes based on your version for correct behavior.

All test is performed in S/4 HANA 2023 FPS02 system.

entry.title: HU based backflush from PSA using Synchronous Posting - BAdI /SCWM/EX_EWM_GI_SORT_STOCK
entry.content:
Business Requirement- Material staging from Warehouse to Production Supply area( Manual Bin to Bin), part of PMR( Manual Staged Items) for batch managed items, system always follow( EWM Hard coded), GR Date and time of Batch during backflush

Customers requirement is to perform backflush on HU level from S4. HU which is moved to PSA has to be consumed first(FIFO), If product has same VFDAT with 3 different HUs, system should consume the HU based on ascending Order( HU which was staged first to PSA ). Deviation from SAP standard Batch level backflush.

Business Problem-In standard SAP using CO11N or COR6N confirmation or BAPI or APIs  or using Manage Production/Process Order Apps  for an EWM storage location, batches are not selected according to the S4 defined batch determination rule (e.g. FEFO or some other LOBM Batch selection Criteria logic). However, for non-EWM storage locations, the batch determination occurs accurately according to settings. This makes customer confused as standard EWM batch determination always FIFO( GR DATE & Time of Batch) irrespective of MBC1( 261) batch condition and CU70 sorting rule opted.

Reason-  SAP has changed batch determination logic for EWM managed storage location in synchronous environment. System considers only those sort fields that correspond to a component of the /SCWM/S_STOCK_SORTED structure, such as WDATU_DATE (Goods Receipt Date), WDATU (Date and Time of Goods Receipt).For storage locations that are relevant to Extended Warehouse Management (EWM), batch picking follows the logic established within EWM. By default, EWM sorts stocks based on the goods receipt date, ensuring efficient batch selection and processing.

Solution: If customers has batch level consumption requirement at FEFO level, customer can  set up  a stock removal rule for the storage type from which the goods are consumed in Customizing for Extended Warehouse Management under Master Data -> Define Storage Type. Also  set up stock removal rule and the sort fields in Customizing for Extended Warehouse Management under Goods Issue Process -> Strategies -> Specify Stock Removal Rule( VFDAT (Shelf Life Expiration Date). However, this only works for Single and Cross Order. For manually staged items, stock removal does not work as staging is purely manual 

However, for  HU level consumption for manually staged products as explained above a BAdI /SCWM/EX_EWM_GI_SORT_STOCK( BAdI is required: Sorting of Stock for Goods Issue in EWM) is required to sort the HUIDENT( HU) based on TRART( Process Category- Internal Movement), Warehouse Task( TANUM), confirmed date and time.

Replication: Below 3 HUs have been manually staged to PSA in ascending Order.

After BAdI implementation, system reads HU movement date from Warehouse to PSA in ascending Order. System should consume 804047 first, then 803913 and then 804046

Stock Situation in EWM after posting.

Performing COR6N( Process Order).Since batch is same for all 3 Hus, S4 does not know which HU is consumed.

Check the HU which is consumed. 803913 is consumed as per FIFO logic written in BAdI /SCWM/EX_EWM_GI_SORT_STOCK because HU 804047( B6) was blocked and BAdI has filtered the stock. 

BADI /SCWM/EX_EWM_GI_SORT_STOCK has 2 major fallback logic, use this fallback logic along with custom one.

  1.  The interface /SCWM/IF_EX_EWM_GI_SORT_STOCK has already logic to filter Blocked stocks in PSA, any HU having Blocked stocks, CO11N/COR6N will filter the stock type and hence consuming only unrestricted F2 stock type( No enhancement is needed, part of standard logic)
  2. The interface /SCWM/IF_EX_EWM_GI_SORT_STOCK has already logic to filter QI stocks from PSA. If customers have requirement to consume QI stocks use  the default implementation (class  /SCWM/CL_EI_EWM_GI_SORT_STOCK) to an own implementation of the BAdI and change the filtering logic. That way customer can  post stocks with inspection reference. Please make sure that the GI posting of QI related stock is not forbidden in  customizing.

Shift in EWM Batch Determination Logic- SAP has introduced a new batch determination class which uses /SCWM/CL_EWM_GM_BATCH_DET & /SCWM/CL_EWM_GM_QUAN_BIN_BDET . This  class is explicitly used in the SAP Extended Warehouse Management (EWM) system that handles batch management functionalities. It includes methods for releasing stock associated with batch-managed products, managing batch details, and processing stock movements. The class interacts with various components to ensure proper handling of goods movements and batch classifications within the warehouse management processes.

Please use the above class and search all the relevant notes to get this functionality implemented at customer system. Customer may have to implement many notes to get BADI and HU based backflush in synchronous environment.

References: 

3375998 - CO11N Wrong determination for EWM Storage Location

3359603 - Wrong Results after Executing EWM Batch Determination Multiple Times

3498544 - QI related Stocks are filtered with synchronous consumption posting

3566352 - synchronous GR with QM reference cannot be reversed

Thanks for reading. All the test and screen shots are performed, taken in S/4 HANA 2023 FPS02 Sandbox system.

entry.title: SAP EWM Podcast - Episode 24 - Is It Art or Can It Be Thrown Away? Archiving in SAP EWM!
entry.content:
SAP EWM Podcast - Episode 24 - Is It Art or Can It Be Thrown Away? Archiving in SAP EWM!

In the world of warehouse management, efficiency and performance are paramount. Yet, one topic often remains in the shadows of project planning and daily operations: archiving in SAP Extended Warehouse Management (EWM). While tidying up may not be anyone’s favorite task—whether at home or in IT—it’s essential for maintaining a clean, performant, and future-proof SAP system.

This blog post explores the importance of archiving in SAP EWM, what data should be archived or deleted, and how it ties into broader concepts like Clean Core and compliance.

You can listen to the podcast episodes in English and in German on Spotify, Amazon Music, Apple Podcasts or Sway! Enjoy!

Why Archiving Matters in SAP Systems

Archiving isn’t just about freeing up space—it’s a strategic necessity. Here are the key reasons to regularly clean up your SAP system:

  • Performance Optimization: Smaller database tables mean faster queries, shorter load times, and improved response times in daily operations.
  • Cost Efficiency: SAP HANA uses RAM-based storage, which is significantly more expensive than traditional disk storage. Reducing data volume can lower costs, especially during migrations to S/4HANA.
  • Clean Core Alignment: A lean system is easier to maintain and upgrade. Archiving supports the Clean Core principle by minimizing unnecessary data and avoiding workarounds that complicate system architecture.

Archiving vs. Deletion: What’s the Difference?

When tidying up, it’s crucial to distinguish between archiving and deletion:

  • Archiving: Data is removed from the operational system but retained in an audit-proof format.
  • Deletion: Data is permanently removed and must be carefully considered, especially in regulated environments.

Regular cleanup jobs are essential for stable SAP EWM operations. Tools like the Database Cockpit (DBA_COCKPIT) or DB02 help identify large tables, such as:

  • BALHDR, BALDAT – Application Logs
  • CDHDR, CDPOS – Change Documents
  • PPFTTRIGG – PPF Actions
  • Various /SCWM/ and /SCDL/ tables in the EWM domain

Check large tables in the SAP system using transaction DB02

 

Guidance and Tools for Cleanup

SAP provides valuable resources to support cleanup efforts. The Operations Guide for SAP S/4HANA, particularly the EWM chapter, outlines cleanup reports and their recommended scheduling. These reports help manage:

  • Application Logs
  • Change Documents
  • PPF Actions
  • Spool Requests
  • Alerts

Be cautious with logging settings, especially for change documents in EWM. Granular settings can lead to massive data volumes, impacting both database size and user performance.

Example of EWM related clean up tasks described in the operations guide

 

Legal and Compliance Considerations

Archiving isn’t just technical—it’s also legal. In Germany, for example, the Tax Code and Commercial Code mandate retention of bookkeeping-relevant data for ten years. Meanwhile, data protection regulations like the EU GDPR require that personal data be stored only as long as necessary.

SAP’s Information Lifecycle Management (ILM) provides tools to manage retention policies and ensure compliance. While this blog doesn’t offer legal advice, it’s important to understand the regulatory framework surrounding data retention.

How Archiving Works in SAP

The SAP archiving process follows a structured approach:

  1. Eligibility Check: The system verifies whether a document is complete and whether all related documents are also archived.
  2. Archive File Creation: Eligible data is written into archive files, which are stored on cost-effective media—often cloud-based solutions like OpenText.

In EWM, for example, archiving warehouse tasks requires that referenced delivery documents are completed. This ensures data integrity and proper sequencing.

Understanding Archive Info Structures

Once data is archived, it must remain accessible for audits or operational needs. This is where archive info structures come into play.

  • These structures are stored in database tables and contain key fields of the archived SAP objects.
  • For example, in warehouse task archiving, fields like warehouse number, task number, item, and a unique archive file identifier are included.
  • Additional fields—such as warehouse order number or storage bin—can be added based on project-specific requirements.
  • A special field called offset indicates the exact location of the object within the archive file, similar to a page number in a book.

Example of archive info structure for warehouse task archiving

 

To access archived data, SAP provides the transaction SARE , which allows users to search and display archived objects across applications. For EWM-specific data, archived documents can often be viewed directly via the SAP EWM warehouse management monitor or standard display transactions.

Once data is successfully archived, it can be deleted from the database. SAP reads the archive file, identifies the original documents, and removes them from the operational system—achieving the goal of a lean and performant database.

SAP ILM: Lifecycle Management and Compliance

SAP Information Lifecycle Management (ILM) extends traditional archiving with features that support:

  • GDPR compliance
  • Data blocking and deletion rules
  • Lifecycle management for both structured and unstructured data

ILM enables organizations to define policies for when data should be blocked, archived, or deleted—especially important for customer or business partner data. It’s available in SAP ERP and S/4HANA as a standard business function, with no additional licensing costs.

Archiving in SAP EWM: Objects and Timing

SAP EWM includes archiving objects for all major business processes, accessible via transaction SARA. These include:

  • Deliveries
  • Warehouse tasks and orders
  • Handling units
  • Physical inventory documents
  • Value-added service documents
  • Waves
  • Transport unit activities
  • MFS telegrams

Example of SAP EWM Archiving Object Value Added Service Order

 

Legal Relevance and Residence Time

Before archiving, organizations must assess:

  • Which data is legally relevant?
    Often, ERP documents like deliveries or material documents are subject to retention laws.

  • When should data be archived?
    This is defined by the residence time—the period data remains in the system after process completion.

SAP provides guidance through SAP note 2378179

  • Warehouse tasks: ~3 months
  • Deliveries: ~6 months

Residence time can also be influenced by internal compliance policies or SLA agreements. For deliveries, EWM offers dedicated customizing options; for other objects, residence time is set during archiving via SARA.

Custom Developments and Archiving Strategy

Custom developments must be considered in any archiving strategy. For custom tables or extensions, developers should plan from the start how data will be removed—either via deletion jobs or custom archiving objects.

Preparing for Migration to S/4HANA EWM

Migrating from SCM-EWM to S/4HANA-EWM is a functional migration, not a technical system conversion. This means:

  • Old data cannot be transferred by default and must be archived beforehand.
  • Master data structures change, affecting the display of archived documents in the new system.

Recommended Approach

  • Archive relevant data before migration.
  • Start fresh in the new system.
  • Use a legacy system or archive viewer to access old documents if needed.

For advanced scenarios, archived files can be converted to be compatible with S/4HANA EWM. This involves reading old archive files, adjusting changed data, and writing new archive files for the target system—a process supported by SAP’s Center of Expertise.

Monitoring and Validation Tools

To ensure your EWM system is properly set up for archiving, SAP offers:

  • The SAP Operations Guide with detailed archiving instructions.
  • EarlyWatch Reports with EWM-specific checks:
    • Are recommended background jobs scheduled?
    • Is archiving correctly configured for EWM objects?

These reports also provide broader insights into system health and performance.

Conclusion: Make Archiving a Priority

Archiving is not just a technical necessity—it’s a strategic enabler for SAP EWM systems. It ensures:

  • System performance and stability
  • Compliance with legal and internal policies
  • Smooth upgrades and migrations

By integrating archiving into your system lifecycle and project planning, you lay the foundation for a clean, efficient, and future-ready SAP EWM environment.

Please visit our SAP EWM Podcast Landing Page with all Episodes, Blog Posts and Podcast Notes!

entry.title: Outbound Transportation from MFG site having EWM,StRM, Lean Warehouse under one Freight Order to DC
entry.content:
Many Industries consider the manufacturing location as a plant in SAP. Under the plant, many storage locations would be available in SAP and some of them would be either IM managed (or Lean Warehouse managed), or Stock Room Managed (StRM) or EWM managed. As a part of the distribution process from the manufacturing site, there would be every chance that the different products from all these types of warehouses need to be shipped to other DC site or to the customer.

This blog covers my personal insights about the outbound process in SAP from MFG (manufacturing) site to other DC (distribution center) or to the customer wherein the different products are picked up from Lean Warehouse, StRM and EWM managed warehouse locations and loaded onto the the same vehicle under the single Freight Order (FO) with the help of SAP EWM and SAP TM ASR integration in basic S/4 HANA licence or in advanced S/4 HANA license using S/4 HANA 2023 FPS02 version. 

Process FLow - 

Process Flow - MFG Site (that has LE, StRM and EWM warehouse) to another DC / Customer in single Freight Order

Master Data -

  1. Maintain Loading Point location for EWM specific warehouse - transaction code # /SCMTMS/LOC3 -

Loading Point - EWM Warehouse

 2. Maintain Loading Point location for StRM specific warehouse - transaction code # /SCMTMS/LOC3 -

Loading Point - StRM Warehouse

3. Maintain Loading Point location for LE specific warehouse - transaction code # /SCMTMS/LOC3 -

Loading Point - LE Warehouse

4. Assign EWM Door in EWM Warehouse to the Loading Point - transaction code # /SCWM/DOOR_SCU -

Assign EWM Door to Loading Point

5. Assign StRM and LE Warehouse specific Door to the Loading Point - transaction code # /SCMTMS/M_ASRDOOR -

Assign StRM and LE Door to Loading Point

Documents in S/4 HANA -

1. Create multiple STO's from MFG plant to another DC.

2. Create multiple OBD's - 

EWM Relevant Delivery

Next -

StRM Relevant Delivery

Next -

Lean WH Relevant Delivery

3. Freight Unit (FU) gets created automatically and is further planned with the help of transportation cockpit automatically / manually and Freight Order (FO) is created and carrier is assigned based on the existing freight agreement arrangements.

Planning of Multiple Freight Units that have warehouse specific Loading Points

4. Perform each warehouse specific steps - picking, packing and staging.

5. Perform Arrival at the Door, Loading, Departure from the Door and PGI at Loading Point of LE Warehouse  - Fiori App - Load/Unload Freight Order.

Update in FO Execution Status after shipping steps in LE Warehouse

6. Perform Arrival at the Door, Loading, Departure from the Door and PGI at Loading Point of StRM Warehouse  - Fiori App - Load/Unload Freight Order.

FO Execution after Shipping steps in StRM Warehouse

7.Perform Arrival at the Door, Loading, Departure from the Door and PGI at Loading Point of EWMM Warehouse - Fiori App - Load/Unload Freight Order.

FO Status Overview at EWM Loading Point

Next -

FO Execution after Shipping steps in EWM Warehouse

Please share your comment and/or feedback in case of any suggestions.
Happy Reading !!!
Thanks
Prashant

Note -  The concept of usage of "Consignment Order" in ASR during the outbound process shipment for multiple customers will be covered in next blog.

entry.title: Integration of Batch-specific Unit of Measure( BSUOM) with EWM on SAP S/4HANA 2023 FPS01
entry.content:
Batch Specific UOM- It is an alternative unit of a material for which the conversion ratio to the base unit of measure can be defined on a batch-specific basis. Batch-specific units of measure are used  for the types of products where there is no fixed conversion factor to convert quantities from AUoM to BUoM. Instead, each batch must be given an individual conversion factor.

Primarily used in Steel, Pharma, Chemicals, Life sciences or its usage can be ubiquitous if Base to AUOM conversion is not fixed for the given product.

Batch Specific UOM( BSUOM) has 2 major attributes.

  1.  Proportion Unit
  2. Product Unit

This blog will focus primarily on Product Unit, Proportion Unit( Active Pharma Ingredient API) will be handled in Part II of this blog series.

Product Unit- Unit of measure that describes the total quantity of a material as an alternative to the base unit of measure.

Example. A piece of  particular material weighs 100 Kg, however in maximum cases, vendor Shipment weight of the product never adheres to fixed conversion ratio maintained in material master like 1 PC=100 KG, sometimes it is more than standard conversion ratio. 

To handle this dynamic UOM conversion & incorporate different weight for each batch, SAP has tool called as Batch Specific UOM( BSUOM) to handle the quantity conversion on 'Batch Basis'. 

There are 3 major elements of Batch Specific UOM( BSUOM)

  • Base UOM
  • Alternate UOM( Product Unit)
  • Intermediate UOM

As a thum rule, Batch specific UOM( BSUOM) is always a alternate UOM which varies dynamically on batch basis. In Our case, Piece is always changing & hence it has to AUOM as 1 PC=105 KG, 1 PC=110 KG, 1PC=115 KG.

Base UOM= KG( Measurable). Alternate UOM= PC( Countable)

Batch Specific UOM( Intermediate UOM)= K/P( KG Per Piece)

How SAP Handles Batch Specific UOM( BSUOM)?

  • Define the KG( Weight) per Piece as a characteristic for batches.( CT04)

  • Create Intermediate UOM- CUNI- KG/P

  • Assign this Characteristics to a class and assign the class to Material Master.

  • Assign the class in Material Master of Product( A planned conversion ratio has to be maintained)

Configuration:

  • Activate Batch Specific UOM

SCM Extended Warehouse Management-->Cross-Process Settings-->Batch Management-->Activate Batch-Specific Units of Measure( This configuration can be activated from Batch Management side as well in OCHA)

  • Configure Product Quantities calculation( OCHA)

Quick check

Create a PO in Product Unit of Measure( AUOM)= PC

Batch specific UOM is supported in Synchronous posting 101 against Purchase Order( MIGO). What is supported and what are restriction is mentioned in SAP note( 3398656 - Release information and restrictions of batch-specific Unit of Measure in EWM on SAP S/4HANA 2023 FPS01

.Receiving of 1 PC.

 

Click on the classification tab and  enter KG/Piece of shipment =105( As lot received from supplier in this example)

Weight is dynamically adjusted bases on Conversion factor at characteristics level

 Doing 2 more GRs for 110 kg & 115 KG corresponding to 1 PC.

Check Stock Situation in EWM & S4.

In EWM, AUoM quantity = BUoM quantity divided by batch conversion factor.
Stock is always moved in the AUoM:
• In warehouse task creation and
• In warehouse task confirmation. 

S4 Stock

Batch Specific UOM( BSUOM) Class:

Rules of product unit of measure in EWM

AUoM quantity = BUoM quantity divided by batch conversion factor.
Stock is always moved in the AUoM:
• In warehouse task creation and
• In warehouse task confirmation.

  • Only one product unit is sent to EWM – if there are multiple product units in the material master, only the leading product unit is sent to EWM.

  • Must to specify product units as alternative units of measure(AUoM) for stock and warehouse tasks in EWM.

  • In EWM, stock is always moved in Product units(AUoM) during warehouse task creation and warehouse task confirmation.

  • EWM cant handle stock in product units in the warehouse without specifying the batch conversion factor during goods receipt posting or initial stock upload at the latest.

  • EWM must have integers for product units, for example, 1 PC, 10 PC, 3 PC – EWM can’t handle stock or warehouse tasks with decimal product unit values.

  • It is possible to  purchase stock and upload stock in base units of measure and in product units.

Supported functionalities in EWM for Batch Specific UOM

Limitation:

• More than one product unit for one material
• All synchronous postings except for movement type 101
• EWM TM integration

  • Decentral EWM( In Roadmap S/4 HANA 2025)

Check SAP note for list of detailed limitation.

3398656 - Release information and restrictions of batch-specific Unit of Measure in EWM on SAP S/4HANA 2023 FPS01

3526169 - BsUoM - Adapted error handling for Product Unit Material

3507014 - Batch-specific quantity conversion - optimization of internal buffers

3585735 - /SCWM/MATERIAL_QUAN_CONV - the quantity ev_quan is calculated incorrectly

3585808 - BSUOM issue with quantity conversion

3449965 - Batch-specific quantity conversion - SP0

3468833 - BSUOM Issue with overpicking proportion unit product

References: SAP® Extended Warehouse Management in SAP S/4HANA ... - SAP Community

Proportion Unit and Product Unit Restrictions | SAP Help Portal

Maintaining Data for Batch-Specific Units of Measure | SAP Help Portal

Batch-Specific Units of Measure in Embedded EWM | SAP Help Portal

 

All tests are performed in S/4 HANA 2023 FPS02 Sandbox System.

entry.title: SAP EWM - Deconsolidation of Handling Unit Internally in Warehouse
entry.content:
The deconsolidation process involves dividing the larger shipment into smaller units, checking their accuracy and condition, and preparing them for final delivery. Efficient load deconsolidation is vital to ensure accurate inventory management, reduce errors and improve overall efficiency. Deconsolidation activity is observed in various industries such as Food & Beverages, Textile, Fashion, Retail, Automotive and Aftermarket sales etc. Deconsolidation in EWM is mainly observed during Inbound but can be performed as an Internal activity as well. 

I have attempted to showcase how it can be achieved in the SAP EWM. 

Configuration:

1) Define Storage types 

SCM EWM > EWM > Master Data > Define Storage Types

Storage type where stock is putawayed when received in a warehouse.

Deconsolidation Work center storage type.

Storage where deconsolidated stock will be kept, from where stock will be picked directly for outbound orders.

Create Activity area, Create Bins and do Bin sorting. 

2) Define POSC

SCM EWM > EWM > Cross-Process Settings> Warehouse Task> Define Process-Oriented Storage Control

3) Define Work Center 

SCM EWM > EWM > Master Data > Work Center > Define Work Center

Assign storage process for deconsolidation.

4) Define Strategies for Stock Removal and Putaway

a) Removal Strategy

SCM EWM> EWM> Goods Issue Process > Strategies > Specify Storage Type Search Sequence

b) Putaway Strategy 

SCM EWM > EWM > Goods Receipt Process > Strategies > Storage Type Search> Define Storage Type Search Sequence for Putaway

Assign Storage Types to Storage Type Search Sequence

Specify Storage Type Search Sequence for Putaway

5) Define Warehouse Process type

SCM EWM > EWM > Cross-Process Settings > Warehouse Task > Define Warehouse Process Type

Assign Storage process in warehouse process type.

Master Data:

Use T code /SCWM/TWORKST to maintain Workcenter Bin

Testing:

1) Use T code /SCWM/ADHU to create a warehouse task for a mix Handling Unit.Enter HU number and click on execute. Click on Create/ Create+Save, HU will be picked, and warehouse task will be created move HU to Deconsolidation Workcenter. 

Confirm open Warehouse task and HU will be moved to Deconsolidation work center.

2) Use /SCWM/DCONS to open Deconsolidation work center.

Create new Handling units and pack quantity into new Handling unit.

Once deconsolidation completed, Click on Complete Process step for HU. 

Note: Recommended to complete HU step one by one to avoid locking. 

HU labels can be printed and pasted. Click on Refresh a new WT will be created to move HU to Final storage. 

All the above steps can be performed in RFUI as well.

entry.title: Changing the batch number of Header Product in Manufacturing Order using BAPI in Exceptional Cases
entry.content:
Problem: Earlier it was not possible to change the Batch number assignment from Production or Process Order using BAPI. Customers had to develop custom program to change the batch number. For some of the customers it is mandatory or part of business process to  change batch number during Receiving if batch is inherited from S4 to EWM. (Unlike many EWM process)

Solution: SAP has released 2 notes.

3361111 - Create order via BAPI: Specify batch

3492667 - Changing batch of order header item via BAPI

With this note, it is possible to have following influence on Manufacturing Order( Production & Process Order)

  1. Blank the batch field using  BAPI_PRODORD_CHANGE for Production Order
  2. Blank the batch field using  BAPI_PROCORD_CHANGE for Process Order
  3. Change the batch field with new batch using BAPI_PRODORD_CHANGE for Production Orders
  4. Change the batch field with new batch using BAPI_PROCORD_CHANGE for Process Orders

In last 2 cases, Batch has to be create afront using MSC1N or BAPI_BATCH_CREATE as above bapi does have capability to create batches on the fly and swap/delete the assignment of Header Material.

Create and release a production with Batch assignment in S4

PMR is created( PMR never contains any batches neither for Header nor for components)

Create a new batch with BAPI_BATCH_CREATE

Trying to change the Batch in RF inherited from S4, EWM does not allows

Customer can build a custom 'Function Code' in RF which can directly create new and change the Batch in MO header using BAPI_BATCH_CREATE and BAPI_PRODORD_CHANGE. To classify the batches in S4, use FM MATERIAL_READ to query the product and change Batch attribute using FM VM_MAINTAIN_MHD if customer needs to update attribute in S4.( Else EWM during receiving updates DOM as current date, please have LOBM_HSDAT and LOBM_VFDAT mandatory in Batch class)

To change the batch, set the BATCH indicator in the ORDERDATAX structure and pass new batch number 0000000483. The system then takes the entry in the BATCH field into account when the BAPI is executed. The batch can also be deleted from the order header. For this, the field BATCH remains empty in the structure ORDERDATA, and the indicator BATCH is set in the structure ORDERDATAX

 

Check Order Now! New Batch is updated in Order Header. 

The header level changes are incorporated in production order admin tab

Now, Try receiving the MO 1000622 with RF. The new batch is updated in Process Order as well in EWM reads the new batch( Embedded EWM S4H 2022)

EWM allows to GR from RF with Batch change conducted via BAPI

Interesting to see how this works in Decentralized EWM on S4H

All test is performed in S4 HANA Embedded 2022 Sandbox system
