entry.title: Basic Configurations for SAP EWM Material Flow System: Part-1
entry.content:
Hello there, Thanks for taking your time to visit the blog. I shall be covering basic configurations/settings for enabling SAP EWM Material Flow Systems in SAP EWM.

Please note that unlike other EWM configurations, all the following configurations may not be the 'base' for you all, you might not need everything based on your business requirements. I have tried to explain every configuration node possible so that readers will get an overall idea on MFS configurations. Please make use of them as per your design requirements.

MFS node consists of the following customizing's, Assuming we have a basic warehouse customizing set-up, Lets begin:

Master Data: Extended Warehouse Management> Material Flow systems> Master Data> Define PLC:

Defining the PLC:
PLC (Programmable Logic Controller) can be defined as an industrial computer which can work 24/7. The primary method for automation between SAP EWM and Automated system is via PLC. 
While we set-up customizing and write technical logic from SAP side, PLC vendor or team has to set up the same in their system- They primarily use ladder logic program to code/configure the logic.

The fields which are not explained in above image is self-explanatory, Opening Performance assistance shall be helping you to get the context.

Communication Channel:
Extended Warehouse Management> Material Flow systems> Master Data> Communication Channel:
Define Communication channel:
Communication Channel is the enabler for PLCs, We define the channels and further definitions come under communication channels. There can be multiple channels for a warehouse/PLC for better load balancing.
Note: There are further set-up under easy access for Communication channels, which enables connectivity with the PLC. Those will be covered under next blog.

Assign Communication Channel to Objects:
Extended Warehouse Management> Material Flow systems> Master Data> Communication Channel to Objects:
This is used in case you are defining multiple communication channel for one PLC. In our case, We are just using a single Communication channel.

Define Communication Point types:
Extended Warehouse Management> Material Flow systems> Master Data> Communication Point Types:

Here, We define the communication types of Communication points, for eg:
1. IP- Identification point: This is where the boxes/pallets arrive and they are scanned by the PLC scanner.

Define Communication Points:
Extended Warehouse Management> Material Flow systems> Master Data> Communication Point:

Communication points are each 'Points' defined at automated areas. It can be a scanning point, intermediate point, end point or whatever business needs it to be. Communication points are assigned to Storage Bins in EWM. 
Fields and details:

Communication points are linked to Bins in Easy access> EWM> Master Data> MFS> Maintain Communication Points.

 

You may also group different communication points together and group them using the "Define communication point Groups" node.

Conveyor segment:
Extended Warehouse Management> Material Flow systems> Master Data>  Define Conveyor Segment:

You may define the segments between two Communication Points and define the capacity for the same here. That is, capacity where number of HUs that can be transported between two segments.

Grouping of segments are also possible under customizing.

Define MFS Queue:
Extended Warehouse Management> Material Flow systems> Master Data> Define MFS Queue:

For Material Flow systems, The telegram message sending to PLC control is at Queue level. For any relevant MFS process, We must chose "MFS" relevant queues, Telegram messages are triggered to subsystem based on this.

Define MFS Resource Type:

Extended Warehouse Management> Material Flow systems> Master Data> Define MFS Resource Type:

You define resource types for all vehicles whose movements are controlled order-by-order by the material flow system under this node.  Eg: Crane, AGV, Robotic hands- All these are defined as different resources within the MFS.

There are several WT confirmation levels possible here based on the level of control you need:

  • One-Step Confirmation:
    The system creates the warehouse task and fills the Source Bin, Destination Bin, and Executing Resource fields.
    It sends a telegram that contains the source bin as the source, and a destination bin as a destination.
    The PLC sends an execution confirmation that the handling unit (HU) has been stored in the destination.
    The warehouse task is confirmed.
  • Two-Step Confirmation:
    The system creates the warehouse task and fills the Source Bin, Destination Bin, and Executing Resource fields. It sends a telegram that contains the source bin as the source, and the destination bin as a destination.
    The PLC sends an execution confirmation that the HU was included in the resource.
    The PLC sends an execution confirmation that the HU has been stored in the destination.
    The warehouse task is confirmed.
  • Two-Step Commissioning:
    The system creates the warehouse task and fills the Source Bin, Destination Bin, and Executing Resource fields.
    It sends a telegram that contains the source bin as the source and a resource.
    The PLC sends an execution confirmation that the HU was included in the resource.
    The warehouse task is confirmed and the subsequent warehouse task is created with a filled destination bin and filled source resource.
    A telegram is sent, which has the destination bin as its destination and a resource.

You may also enable interleaving for resources here. Eg: to avoid any Vehicles return without any goods.

Define Aisles and Levels Accessible by Communication points:

Extended Warehouse Management> Material Flow systems> Master Data>  Define Aisles and Levels accessible by Communication Points:
The functionality is self explanatory: If you maintain entries for your communication point and maintain the aisles or bins, It enables the Aisles and levels which can be accessible by the CPs. please note that this configuration is used when you use Case conveyor systems.

To understand the difference between different systems under MFS, Please refer to my previous blog: 
SAP EWM MFS: Pallet, Case conveyor systems 

Making use of Multi-depth bins for storage in ASRS:

Extended Warehouse Management> Material Flow systems> Master Data>  Define required bin depth for HU types/Storage bin types:

Multi-depth bins storage and usage based on HU, storage bin parameters or dimensions can be configured under the below nodes. You may maintain the required depth for the HU or Maximum depth for the bins here.
Also, additionally- If you need to assign x,y,z coordinates- you may assign a communication point to a storage bin in EWM and maintain the coordinates at bin level.

Storage Control:
The storage control level node consists of LOSC configurations, Which I do no intend to cover here since LOSC configurations, testing documents are available online.

Rest of the settings shall be covered in next blog.

Thank you,
Aman Orchard.

entry.title: SAP EWM Transactions
entry.content:
SAP Extended Warehouse Management (EWM) is a powerful solution designed to optimize complex warehouse processes. Whether you're managing inbound deliveries, outbound shipments, or internal stock movements, EWM provides a rich set of transaction codes (T-codes) to streamline operations.

In this blog, we’ll explore the most essential EWM transaction codes categorized by business processes, helping you navigate the system with confidence.

🔹 Inbound Delivery Processing

Inbound processes are critical for receiving goods efficiently. Key T-codes include:

  • /SCWM/IDN – Maintain Inbound Delivery Notification
  • /SCWM/PRDI – Maintain Inbound Delivery
  • /SCWM/GRPE – GR Preparation for External Procurement
  • /SCWM/GRPI – GR Preparation for Production
  • /SCWM/UNLOAD – Unload Goods
  • /SCWM/EGR – Maintain Expected Goods Receipt

🔹 Outbound Delivery Processing

Outbound transactions ensure timely and accurate dispatch of goods:

  • /SCWM/ODR – Maintain Outbound Delivery Request
  • /SCWM/PRDO – Maintain Outbound Delivery Order
  • /SCWM/FD – Final Delivery
  • /SCWM/LOAD – Load Goods
  • /SCWM/SGI – Post Goods Issue

🔹 Posting Changes & Internal Movements

These transactions help manage stock adjustments and transfers:

  • /SCWM/IM_DR – Maintain Posting Change Request
  • /SCWM/IM_PC – Maintain Posting Change
  • /SCWM/IM_ST – Internal Stock Transfer
  • /SCWM/POST – Make Posting Change

🔹 Warehouse Task & Order Processing

Warehouse tasks are the backbone of physical movements:

  • /SCWM/ADPROD – Create Product Warehouse Task
  • /SCWM/TO_CONF – Confirm Warehouse Task
  • /SCWM/TODLV_I – Putaway WT for Inbound Delivery
  • /SCWM/TODLV_O – Stock Removal for Outbound Delivery

🔹 Physical Inventory

Accurate inventory counts are vital for operational integrity:

  • /SCWM/PI_CREATE – Create Physical Inventory Document
  • /SCWM/PI_COUNT – Enter Count Results
  • /SCWM/DIFF_ANALYZER – Analyze Differences
  • /SCWM/WM_ADJUST – Post Differences to ERP

🔹 Quality Management

Ensure product quality through integrated QM processes:

  • /SCWM/VAS_I – VAS in Goods Receipt
  • /SCWM/VAS_O – VAS in Goods Issue
  • /SCWM/VASEXEC – Confirm VAS Execution

🔹 Monitoring & Reporting

Stay on top of warehouse performance:

  • /SCWM/MON – Warehouse Monitor
  • /SCWM/ERP_STOCKCHECK – Compare ERP and EWM Stock
  • /SCWM/ACTLOG – Activate Application Log

🔹 Other Useful Transactions

  • /SCWM/MAT1 – Maintain Warehouse Product
  • /SCWM/PACKSPEC – Maintain Packaging Specification
  • /SCWM/LS01 – Create Storage Bin
  • /SCWM/SLOT – Slot Products for Warehouse

📌 Tips for Navigating EWM Transactions

  • Use SE93 to explore transaction codes and their packages.
  • Use SE80 to browse transaction folders by package.
  • Refer to SAP Notes like 2524406 for mapping GUI transactions to Fiori apps.

✅ Conclusion

Mastering these transaction codes empowers warehouse professionals to execute tasks efficiently, reduce errors, and improve overall logistics performance. Whether you're a functional consultant or a warehouse manager, understanding these T-codes is key to unlocking the full potential of SAP EWM.

Ref Link: https://help.sap.com/docs/SUPPORT_CONTENT/sewm/3354623031.html

entry.title: SAP Extended Warehouse Management for SAP S/4HANA Cloud, Private Edition, 2025 FPS00 – What’s New
entry.content:
We have recently released the latest updates for SAP Extended Warehouse Management for SAP S/4HANA Cloud, private edition, 2025 FPS00. With this release, we further expand the AI capabilities available for SAP EWM, add in more functionalities and scenarios for the Advanced Shipping & Receiving integration, deliver a host of extensibility and user experience improvements, improve the Quality Management and Production integrations, and much more.

ADVANCED SHIPPING & RECEIVING

Integration between transportation and warehouse logistics is a significant contributor towards logistics efficiency, synchronizing process changes between warehouse and transportation, reducing overall logistics-costs by optimizing and streamlining freight planning with warehouse execution. To further tighten this integration, with this release we provide the following enhancements and updates to Advanced Shipping & Receiving. Cross-Delivery Handling Units

With this feature, you can use cross-delivery handling units (HUs) in the outbound process with Advanced Shipping and Receiving. The deliveries that are packed together must fulfill several conditions. The system runs the checks when you set the status of the delivery to Ready for Shipping, or in the case of immediate loading, when you set the status of the HUs to Packed for Shipping.

The cross-delivery HUs must meet the following conditions in SAP EWM:

  • All the deliveries involved must have transportation planning type E or F
  • All deliveries have the same ship-to party
  • Either all the deliveries are relevant for immediate loading or none of them are
  • You must set the status Ready for Shipping for all the outbound delivery orders involved in the cross-delivery network at the same time. The checks on all HUs or deliveries must be OK to set the status.
  • All the deliveries involved must have status Picking Completed before you set the status Ready for Shipping.

Transportation Management performs checks for shipping points, loading points, doors, and other transport related attributes on the cross-delivery HUs. For more information, see Integration of Cross-Delivery Handling Units in Advanced Shipping and Receiving.

You can use cross-delivery HUs in the warehouse driven process (transportation type E) and the transport driven process (transportation type F)

If you are using immediate loading, you can reverse the status Packed for Shipping for a cross-delivery HU if this HU is not yet loaded and Ready for Shipping is not set. You can reverse the status Ready for Shipping even if loading HUs has already started.

Harmonized Outbound Delivery Update in Logistics Execution

With this feature, we ensure that the changes in Logistic Execution process are harmonized across ERP Logistics Execution (LE), Extended Warehouse Management (EWM) and Transportation Management (TM). For example:

  • You can change specific values of an outbound delivery in LE after the outbound delivery is distributed to EWM. Any changes you make in LE outbound delivery are automatically distributed to EWM and TM.
  • You can also add more items to an outbound delivery in LE after the delivery is distributed to EWM and freight units are created in TM.

In addition, some fields might be read-only in Change Outbound Delivery, depending on the warehouse processing status of the outbound delivery. For example, if the delivery has the status Ready for Warehouse Processing, some fields might not be editable in Change Outbound Delivery. To see the full list of the fields that are editable please read the Help Portal page “Updating Outbound Deliveries in Logistics Execution”.

Enablement of Stock Transport Order Execution for the inbound process in embedded EWM

This feature enables you to process stock transport orders (STO) for sending and receiving warehouses in one Freight Order across EWM managed warehouses and non-EWM managed MM-IM storage locations, provided that embedded EWM/TM is used. Such STO enables the transfer of goods and materials from one plant to another within the same company code (intra-company).

In a two-step STO process, outbound and inbound deliveries are created, and the freight units (FU) are reassigned from the outbound to the inbound delivery. The posting of goods issue triggers the creation of an inbound delivery and the automatic reassignment of the FU from the outbound to the inbound delivery.

As soon as the FU is assigned the inbound delivery as its predecessor document, the receiving processes such as check-in, unloading and goods receipt can be processed.

This feature provides visibility throughout the end-to-end process – from sending shipping point to receiving point within one business document. This feature is only available in embedded EWM and TM deployment.

New Handling Execution Status: Cargo Ready for Loading

With this feature, we introduce a new execution status Cargo Ready for Loading, which, starts the creation of customs invoice and export declaration before the goods are loaded onto a truck in an Advanced Shipping and Receiving process.

The status is available on the freight order (FO) maintenance UI in Transportation Management (TM). When in use, you can set the status after the warehouse processing status is set to Completed. The status precedes handling execution status Loading Completed and can be configured as a prerequisite to customs documents requests. You can revert the status any time before the customs documents have been created.

Additionally, you can set up your system so that automatic consignment order creation happens when the status is set. Similarly, you can configure it so that the status triggers output processing such as the printing of transport documents or advanced shipping notifications (ASN). To find out more please read the Help Portal page “New Handling Execution Status: Cargo Ready for Loading”.

INTEGRATION

Integration is a core pillar of our investments, by which we provide a deep and native integration with SAP S/4HANA Private Cloud solution components, along with SAP's cloud offerings for seamless integration of comprehensive logistics end-to-end processes incl. production integration, dangerous goods handling, customs processing and more. To that end, in this release we deliver the following enhancements.

Partial Goods Issue for Component Consumption & COGI split

With this feature, if you use synchronous goods movements for the consumption of components by manufacturing, you can split the goods issue for components consumed from EWM-managed storage locations if less than the full quantity needed is available on the production staging area (PSA). The system posts the goods issue for the available quantities and posts the remaining quantity to the Reprocess Goods Movements app (COGI). This feature is only available in embedded EWM.

The following restrictions apply to the COGI-split available with SAP S/4HANA 2025, FPS0:

  • You can't use this feature to split goods issue for components that require serial numbers.
  • You can't use this feature to split goods issue for batch-managed components.

To split goods issue quantities, you must activate it in one of the following Customizing activities:

  • For Repetitive Manufacturing, in Customizing for Production under Repetitive Manufacturing > Control > Define Repetitive Manufacturing Profiles
  • For Discrete Manufacturing, in Customizing for Production under Shop Floor Control > Master Data > Define Production Scheduling Profile for Discrete Manufacturing
  • For Process Manufacturing, in Customizing for Production Planning for Process Industries under Process Order > Master Data > Define Production Scheduling Profile for Process Manufacturing

EWM/QM Serial Number Integration

This feature enables you to record a quality inspection result for a specific serialized product in the Quality Management (QM) component of SAP S/4HANA by recording a usage decision for the serialized product with reference to its serial number. The system integrates the serial number to the inspection lot in the QM component during the goods receipt posting of the stock item. Note that this feature is available only for inspection object type (IOT) Q-Inspection Product/Batch Inbound Del. (IOT 4) and Q-Inspection Product/Batch Whse-Internal (IOT 5).

To enable this feature, you select the checkbox Serial No. Integr. (Enable Serial Number Integration) for IOT 4 or IOT 5 in Customizing for Extended Warehouse Management under Cross-Process Settings > Quality Management > Basics and Integration > Define and Activate Warehouse-Dependent IOTs.

For more information on recording a quality inspection result for a specific serialized product in the Quality Management (QM) component of SAP S/4HANA, please read the Help Portal page “Serial Numbers in Inspection Results”.

Deactivation of Quality Inspections Based on Movement Type

With this feature, you can deactivate quality inspections for inspection object type (IOT) Q-Inspection Product/Batch Inbound Del. (IOT 4) based on movement type settings in the Quality Management (QM) component of SAP S/4HANA. If the quality inspections are deactivated, the system doesn’t create an inspection request (inspection document or inspection lot).

The inspection process in EWM must be integrated with the QM component.

  • The QM component is in SAP S/4HANA 2025 or later.
  • You’ve deactivated quality inspections for the movement type in Customizing for Quality Management under Quality Inspection > Inspection Lot Creation > Inspection for Goods Movement.
  • You’ve deactivated quality inspections for IOT 4 based on movement type settings in the QM component.

To do this, you select the checkbox QM Deact. MvmtTyp (Deactivate Inspections Based on QM Movement Type Settings) in Customizing for Extended Warehouse Management under Cross-Process Settings > Quality Management > Basics and Integration > Define and Activate Warehouse-Dependent IOTs. For additional information, please consult the Help Portal page “Deactivation of Quality Inspections Based On Movement Type”.

SAP Extended Warehouse Management for SAP S/4HANA Cloud, private edition and SAP Batch Release Hub for Life Sciences integration

Support the integration of SAP Extended Warehouse Management for SAP S/4HANA Cloud, private edition and SAP Batch Release Hub for Life Sciences for both embedded and decentralized extended warehouse management.

The following integration scenarios are provided for SAP Batch Release Hub for Life Science integration:

  • Read the handling units with inspection lots from SAP Extended Warehouse Management for SAP S/4HANA Cloud, private edition and SAP Batch Release Hub for Life Sciences.
  • Stock the posting from SAP Batch Release Hub for Life Sciences to SAP Extended Warehouse Management for SAP S/4HANA Cloud, private edition based on inspection decision on handling units.

Integration with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition

With this feature, you can integrate SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition with decentralized SAP Extended Warehouse Management for SAP S/4HANA Cloud, private edition.

You can use this integration if you want to start a business process in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition but also want to use features that are available only in decentralized EWM based on SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition. Learn more about integration aspects and supported features via our SAP blog  

The SAP Extended Warehouse Management FAQ Series: SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud Integration and the Knowledge Base Article “3376453 - SAP S/4HANA 2023 FPS00, FPS01, FPS02 and FPS03: Release information and restrictions for EWM in SAP S/4HANA”.

EXTENSIBILITY & USABILITY

The Clean Core Extensibility strategy aims to provide a modern and powerful integration option for customers and partners. Alongside supporting this strategy, we continuously adapt solution content to modernize and simplify the user experience. By regularly updating and refining SAP Extended Warehouse Management for SAP S/4HANA Cloud, private edition, we ensure we remain relevant and effective in meeting current needs. This year’s October release we deliver the following updates.

Monitor, RFUI, Interfaces enhancements

  • Warehouse Order Splitting in the Pick by Cart App - With this feature, you can use the Pick by Cart app to split a warehouse order when you've only partially completed a picking task. If you need to leave the warehouse order with only some items picked, you can choose to first unload the handling unit at its destination location and automatically split the warehouse order or just split the warehouse order. This helps you to more efficiently hand over the picking task to another warehouse worker.

  • Screen Zooming on Radio Frequency Devices - With this feature, you can enable zooming of radio frequency (RF) screens on presentation devices when using SAP GUI for HTML. For example, you can enable automatic zooming or fixed factor zooming of between 50 and 300 percent. You use zooming to fit RF screens to the display of the presentation device as well as possible. For more information please read the Help Portal page “Screen Zooming on Radio Frequency Devices”.

API updates: ODATA Services

  •  Posting changes in Physical Stock - With this feature you can perform several posting changes for the stock in your warehouse. You can make the following changes to the stock:
    • Change the stock type
    • Change the party entitled to dispose
    • Change product or batch
    • Change sales order or project reference
    • Change stock owner and usage

  • Visibility of Custom Fields in OData APIs – With this feature, you can use the Custom Fields app to make your custom fields appear in the OData APIs Warehouse Inbound Delivery and Warehouse Outbound Delivery Order, if your custom fields also appear in the business contexts Warehouse Request Header or Warehouse Request Item. You still use the Custom Fields app to add custom fields to Warehouse Request Header and Warehouse Inbound Delivery.
  • Warehouse Order Business Events – With this feature, the Warehouse Order business object triggers the following events when processing the warehouse tasks of a warehouse order:
    • Warehouse task created
    • Warehouse task confirmed
    • Warehouse task canceled
    • Warehouse task activated

Events are not triggered retroactively for existing warehouse orders and warehouse tasks. Events for warehouse tasks are triggered only when new warehouse tasks are processed or changes are made to existing warehouse orders and warehouse tasks (for example, a confirmation or cancellation).

API updates: Internal API

  • Enhancements to Goods Movements in EWM and Inventory Management – With this feature, you can now use the application programming interface (API) API for Goods Movement in EWM and IM (/SCWM/IF_API_IM_GOODSMVT) to post goods receipt with reference to purchase order items (standard and stock transfer items), order items, and their reversals. The API enables you to post goods movements (goods receipts, goods issues, transfer postings, and their reversals) in Inventory Management and Extended Warehouse Management for embedded warehouses. The new goods movements can be posted for unpacked or packed items, including nested and mixed handling units (HUs). These goods movements are posted to the warehouse and to Inventory Management at the same time using movement type 101 or 102, or your own movement type that has been created as a copy of these movement types. For more information on these enhancements, please read the Help Portal page linked here.

CONTINUOUS IMPROVEMENTS

Our commitment to modernization and continuous improvements not only enhances functionality but also provides users with a seamless and intuitive interaction, helping businesses drive efficiency, optimize processes, and deliver superior experiences to their stakeholders. To that end, I would like to highlight the following feature.

Reverse Goods Receipt after Final Putaway for Stock from External Procurement

With this feature, you can also reverse goods receipt for stock from external procurement even after final putaway. The reversal is available in the warehouse monitor, as the Reverse after Putaway method in the nodes for physical stocks, for example, Stock and Bin > Physical Stock.

You can also use the API interface /SCWM/IF_API_RVS_STOCK_PTWY in a custom development to perform the reversal. If you are using decentralized SAP Extended Warehouse Management for SAP S/4HANA Cloud, private edition, and your processes use Logistics Execution (LE) deliveries, you must set the Control Process: Extended Reversal After Final Putaway field to Allow for Completed LE Delivery in Customizing for Extended Warehouse Management under Interfaces > ERP Integration > ERP Integration for Decentralized EWM > Set Control Parameters for ERP Version Control.

The Business Add-In (BAdI) Reverse Goods Receipt after Final Putaway (External Procurement) allows you to implement additional checks at reversal of goods receipt after final putaway. See Customizing for Extended Warehouse Management under Business Add-Ins (BAdIs) for Extended Warehouse Management > Cross-Process Settings > Goods Movement Postings > BAdI: Reverse Goods Receipt after Final Putaway.

ARTIFICIAL INTELLIGENCE IN WAREHOUSE MANAGEMENT

Predictive Labor Demand Planning

With the SAP S/4HANA 2023 FPS03 release, we delivered the foundation of predictive labor demand planning (LDP) that we’ve been able to predict planned workload on Outbound Delivery Order and Warehouse Order/Warehouse Task level based on historical data collected from RF Picking and Packing activities. With this release, you can now use machine learning empowered workload forecast to anticipate future labor needs for better operational planning and resource allocation. The solution uses a minimum of 3 weeks of historical data and predicts the short-term labor demand in next days or weeks. Using SAP Smart Business dashboards, it gives insights of workload duration, calculated Full-time-equivalents (FTE) and other important aspects such as volume, weight, and number of expected items. The feature also takes factory calendar into consideration and offers extensibility possibilities that allow customers to influence on forecast calculations, making the solution adaptable to various warehouse environments.

Joule Navigation & Integration to the Warehouse Outbound Process

There is more to discuss regarding AI features available to EWM this year, but as the Joule development and release schedule has a different cadence to our regular mainline developments and releases, we feel that this topic deserves its own separate blog post. We will revisit later this fall and discuss more details on how Joule can assist both new and seasoned warehouse operators alike in navigating to required documents and FIORI apps, as well as help them throughout the warehouse outbound process. Stay tuned for more.

FIND OUT MORE!

To see more details on the above-mentioned topics as well as see what other enhancements we delivered with this release, I highly encourage you to explore our latest “SAP Extended Warehouse Management for SAP S/4HANA Cloud, private edition” slide deck.

You can also find more technical details and documentation on the above listed topic and others we left out via the “What’s New” viewer on the Help Documentation portal.

For more information about SAP Extended Warehouse Management, please follow us on social media, our YouTube channel or our community pages:

SAP EWM Community

SAP YouTube Channel

EWM LinkedIn Community

SAP Extended Warehouse Management Roadmap Explorer

Release information and restrictions of embedded EWM on SAP S/4HANA 2025 

Release information and restrictions of Decentralized EWM on SAP S/4HANA 2025 

For a complete list of Q&A from the EWM community, please access this link:
https://answers.sap.com/tags/01200615320800000705

In case you do not find your specific question there, feel free to post your question via the following form:
https://answers.sap.com/questions/ask.html?primaryTagId=01200615320800000705

entry.title: Goods Receipt Reversal for External Procurement in EWM - SAP S/4HANA 2025
entry.content:
In this blog post, I would like to explain how to cancel the Goods Receipt after Final Putaway for External Procurement in Extended Warehouse Management, in addition to demonstrating the process steps for testing, we will also discuss about potential errors and current limitations.

This new Monitor Mehtod is available in both EWM deployments: Embedded and Decentralized.

Background Information:

With the new Method 'Reverse after Putaway' in Warehouse Management Monitor (i.e. As of SAP S/4HANA 2025 FPS0), it is now finally possible to reverse a goods receipt for an inbound delivery/item in external procurement scenario (e.g. Purchase Order) in EWM, even if the Putaway Warehouse Task is already confirmed.

This gives the warehouse team more flexibility to trigger GR reversal at anytime when the error is observed maybe during picking, as long as the reference purchase documents are still exist in system (i.e. not Archived).

The new Monitor Method (Reverse after Putaway) can be found in the following nodes in SAP Warehouse Management Monitor report (/SCWM/MON):
- Stock and Bin -> Physical Stock 
- Stock and Bin -> Storage Bin -> Physical Stock


Figure 01 - Simple Inbound Process Flow

Prerequisites:

  • Completion Status (DCO) for delivery item to be cancelled must be equal to 9-Completed
  • Purchase document is not archived
  • Quality inspection document is completed (if exists)
  • Authorization object /SCWM/SLFU with the value RS for Reverse Stock from External Procurement is assigned to your user.

Configuration Steps:

This configuration step is only required in Decentralized EWM deplopyment.

- Allow Reversal after Putaway for Completed LE Delivery
Navigate to SPRO -> Extended Warehouse Management-> Interfaces->ERP Integration->ERP Integration for Decentralized EWM-> Set Control Parameters for ERP Version Control


Figure 02 - Set Control Parameters for ERP Version Control

Testing Steps:

NOTE: The following testing scenario has been executed on SAP S/4HANA OP2025 FPS00 with Embedded EWM.

Scenario: GR Reversal for Inbound Delivery with reference to a Purchase Order:
In this scenario we will post goods receipt for an inbound delivery created with reference to a purchase order, then we will trigger the goods receipt reversal for the received delivery item via the new Monitor Method (Reverse after Putaway) in Warehouse Monitor report.

1- Create Purchase Order (Tx. ME21N / App. Create Purchase Order - Advanced)


Figure 03 - Create Purchase Order

2- Create Inbound Delivery in Logistics Execution (Tx. VL31N / App. Create Inbound Delivery)


Figure 04 - Create Inbound Delivery in LE

3- Post Goods Receipt in EWM (Tx. /SCWM/PRDI / App. Maintain Inbound Deliveries)


Figure 05 - Post GR in EWM


4- Create Putaway Warehouse Tasks  (Tx. /SCWM/PRDI / App. Create Warehouse Tasks - Inbound Delivery)


Figure 06 - Create Putaway WTs

Hint: don't forget to take a note of the destination storage bin number, to use it later on during the reversal step.

5- Confirm Putaway Warehouse Tasks (Tx. /SCWM/MON / App. Warehouse Monitor)


Figure 07 - Confirm Putaway WTs

6- Reverse Goods Receipt in EWM (Tx. /SCWM/MON / App. Warehouse Monitor)
 - Navigate to Warehouse Management Monitor report -> Stock and Bin -> Physical Stock.
- Select the stock line and click on More Methods -> Reverse after Putaway.


Figure 08/A - Select Reverse after Putaway method

 - Ensure to enter the exact quantity to be reversed. 
- You need to enter Inbound Delivery and Item numbers as well (if not proposed by system, in case of multiple reference documents exist).
- Then click Post GR Reversal button.


Figure 08/B - Post GR Reverseal in EWM

Hint: Material Document year/number/item could be entered as well if desired.

- If goods receipt reversal is successful, then a Warehouse Task of category 6-Goods Issue Posting will be created.


Figure 08/C - WT for GI is created

7- Check Inbound Delivery in EWM (Tx. /SCWM/PRDI / App. Maintain Inbound Deliveries) - Optional


Figure 09 - Check Inbound Delivery in EWM

In EWM inbound delivery, Goods Receipt and Putaway statutes will remain Completed (no changes).

8- Check Inbound Delivery in Logistics Execution  (Tx. VL33N / App. Display Inbound Delivery) - Optional


Figure 10/A - Check Inbound Delivery GM Status in LE

In LE inbound delivery, the Goods Receipt status will remain Completed (no changes).


Figure 10/B - Check Inbound Delivery Document Flow in LE

But in the document flow, a goods reversal material document (w/ movement type 102) will be created and added.

9- Check Purchase Order History in ERP (Tx. ME23N  / App. Display Purchase Order)


Figure 11 - Check PO History in ERP

NOTE: In case the missing item has been delivered by supplier later on after the goods receipt reversal for the same item was executed, a new inbound delivery should be created in this case as re-posting goods receipt for same inbound delivery item which was reversed is not possible.

 

Common Errors during Goods Receipt Reversal:

- M7328 - Deficit of Delivered quantity:
In case you enter higher quantity than original delivery item quantity.

- /SCWM/GM401 - Reversal for stock assigned to reference documents is not allowed:
In case you select a stock line with a delivery reference (i.e. DCO <> 9) or you select a stock item with open quality inspection document.

- /SCWM/GM402 - Stock Information in delivery/item - doesn't match selected stock:
In case you select a different stock line that doesn't match the inserted delivery information.

 

Out of Scope:

  • Posting goods receipt for same inbound delivery item which was revesred.
  • Serial number managed materials. (only via API is possible)
  • Catch weight managed materials.
  • Purchase documents are archived.
  • STO, Merchandise Cross docking, and TCD.

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Conclusion:

It's now possible to reverse goods receipt after final putaway in EWM for external procurment scenario, using the new Monitor Method - Reversal after Putaway in Warehouse Management Report, the warehouse user is now able to trigger goods receipt reversal in EWM and ERP respectively without too much complexity or additional technical knowledge. 

You can also use the API interface /SCWM/IF_API_RVS_STOCK_PTWY in a custom development to perform the reversal.

For more information about reversal after putaway, please check Reversal of Goods Receipt from External Procurement | SAP Help Portal.

For more information about other new EWM features in S/4HANA 2025 FPS00, please check the following blog post by Gheorghe Ceres: SAP Extended Warehouse Management for SAP S/4HANA Cloud, Private Edition, 2025 FPS00 – What’s New
 
Learn more about SAP Premium Engagement and how a global team of experts can help you to get the most out of your SAP solutions.

If you already are a Premium Engagement customer, contact your Technical Quality Manager (TQM) to discuss how Premium Engagement services can help you with a custom-tailored and efficient service portfolio to make your project a success!

#CoE EMEA SCM1
